answers.explanation:
There are multiple deep creamy white/yellow chorioretinal lesions in the peripapillary region OU (red arrows) extending into the mid-peripheral retina. The optic nerve head is unremarkable and there are no clinical abnormalities in the retinal vasculature.

Describe the OCT macula images.

There are mild ERMs OU. There is loss of the outer-retinal banding (ellipsoid zone and external limiting membrane) in the parafoveal region OU (yellow circles). There is no discernible intraretinal fluid or subretinal fluid.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: Based on the history, fundus findings, and OCT findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.answerText: A. Multiple Evanescent White Dot Syndrome (MEWDS)
B. Acute Posterior Multifocal Placoid Pigment Epitheliopathy (APMPPE)

answers.explanation: Birdshot chorioretinopathy is a white-dot syndrome that often presents with bilateral cream-colored oval chorioretinal lesions in the peripapillary area. The lesions are typically oriented around the optic nerve head. OCT may demonstrate disruption of the ellipsoid zone which contributes to vision loss (1). Cystoid macular edema and vitreous cells may also be present, which can impact visual acuity.

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text: Which of the following haplotypes is most strongly associated with birdshot chorioretinitis?

answers.explanation: The HLA-A29 haplotype exhibits the strongest correlation between a human class I MHC molecule and any disease. Between 80% and 98% of patients with birdshot chorioretinitis are HLA-A29 positive, compared to 7% in the general population, and this positivity is associated with a 224-fold increase in the relative risk of developing the disease (2). HLA-B27 is associated with ankylosing spondylitis and anterior uveitis, while HLA-B51 is linked to Behçet’s disease. HLA-DR1 and HLA-DR4 are associated with Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada (VKH) disease.

![](/content/media/uveitis_19_6.avif)

![](/content/media/uveitis_19_7.avif)

![](/content/media/uveitis_19_8.avif)

Which of the following descriptions of the IVFA photos is most accurate?

answers.answerText: A. Hyperfluorescence in the areas corresponding to the lesions and peripapillary leakage, with vasculitis in zone 1 only
B. Late hyperfluorescence in the areas corresponding to the lesions and peripapillary leakage, with vasculitis in zones 1-3
answers.explanation:
Optic disc hyperfluorescence (red circle) is a common finding in birdshot chorioretinopathy but is nonspecific (3). There is extensive dye leakage in all zones of the retina, suggestive of retinal vasculitis (yellow arrows). The chorioretinal lesions in birdshot chorioretinopathy classically demonstrate early blockage with late staining on IVFA. Indocyanine green (ICG) angiography may reveal even more lesions than are visible clinically or on IVFA.

![](/content/media/uveitis_19_9.avif)

answers.answerText: C. Hyperfluorescence of the macula and in the areas corresponding to the lesions and peripapillary leakage, with vasculitis in zones 1-3
